articles.headline: G.O.P. on Defensive as Analysts Question Party’s Fiscal Policy
articles.snippet: Onetime standard-bearers of Republican economic philosophy are among those saying the short-term focus should be on stimulus.
articles.abstract: Onetime standard-bearers of Republican economic philosophy are among those saying the short-term focus should be on stimulus.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The boasts of Congressional Republicans about their cost-cutting victories are ringing hollow to some well-known economists, financial analysts and corporate leaders, including some Republicans, who are expressing increasing alarm over Washington’s new austerity and antitax orthodoxy.

articles.headline: All the Ways That Stocks Churn Your Stomach
articles.snippet: It’s valuable to look closely at the range of feelings stirred by wild market swings, and deploy some countermeasures.
articles.abstract: It’s valuable to look closely at the range of feelings stirred by wild market swings, and deploy some countermeasures.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the stock market is a reflection of the stew of our emotions, it’s pretty clear that nobody knew how to feel this week.

articles.headline: Money No Obstacle as Perry Joins G.O.P. Race
articles.snippet: The Texas governor has a vast network of wealthy supporters eager to bankroll his presidential ambitions.
articles.abstract: The Texas governor has a vast network of wealthy supporters eager to bankroll his presidential ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Gov. Rick Perry of Texas arrives in South Carolina on Saturday to begin his presidential campaign, he might claim any number of credentials for the country’s top office: Creator of jobs. Cutter of taxes. Defender of gun rights.

articles.headline: Global Jitters Gather Over State of Société Générale
articles.snippet: Société Générale is only France’s third-largest bank, but it is a global player with big holdings in bad European debt.
articles.abstract: Société Générale is only France’s third-largest bank, but it is a global player with big holdings in bad European debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s a bank that hasn’t been much on Wall Street’s radar since the days of the A.I.G. bailout.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Strikers Trade Barbs With Verizon
articles.snippet: Workers on strike against Verizon accused it of “destroying middle-class jobs.” Verizon said the workers were adequately paid.
articles.abstract: Workers on strike against Verizon accused it of “destroying middle-class jobs.” Verizon said the workers were adequately paid.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since 45,000 workers began their strike against Verizon Communications on Sunday, their unions have repeatedly stressed one point: Verizon’s push for concessions would “destroy middle-class jobs” and “push workers out of the middle class.”

articles.headline: Foreigners Follow Money to Booming Brazil, Land of $35 Martini
articles.snippet: The turnaround from the nation’s days as a major debtor nation has also attracted Brazilians back from abroad.
articles.abstract: The turnaround from the nation’s days as a major debtor nation has also attracted Brazilians back from abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Pondering the financial storms lashing Europe and the United States, Seth Zalkin, a casually dressed American banker, sipped a demitasse and seemed content with his decision to move here in March with his wife and son.

articles.headline: Qaeda Trying to Harness Toxin for Bombs, U.S. Officials Fear
articles.snippet: According to classified reports, Al Qaeda’s Yemeni branch is trying to acquire castor beans for making ricin, a toxin so deadly that just a speck can kill.
articles.abstract: According to classified reports, Al Qaeda’s Yemeni branch is trying to acquire castor beans for making ricin, a toxin so deadly that just a speck can kill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American counterterrorism officials are increasingly concerned that the most dangerous regional arm of Al Qaeda is trying to produce the lethal poison ricin, to be packed around small explosives for attacks against the United States.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: A County in Alabama Puts Off Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: Gov. Robert Bentley urged Jefferson County, Ala., to strive to avoid bankruptcy because it could ripple out and hurt the credit of the whole state.
articles.abstract: Gov. Robert Bentley urged Jefferson County, Ala., to strive to avoid bankruptcy because it could ripple out and hurt the credit of the whole state.
articles.lead_paragraph: Officials in troubled Jefferson County, Ala., rebuffed a settlement offer with creditors on Friday but refrained from declaring bankruptcy, saying they wanted to try to reach a better deal in face-to-face negotiations with their lenders.

articles.headline: Faltering Rhode Island City Tests Vows to Pensioners
articles.snippet: As Central Falls, R.I., sorts out its finances after filing for bankruptcy, it is trying to put bondholders in line for payment ahead of pensioners.
articles.abstract: As Central Falls, R.I., sorts out its finances after filing for bankruptcy, it is trying to put bondholders in line for payment ahead of pensioners.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the small, beleaguered city of Central Falls, R.I., filed for bankruptcy this month, it sought to cut the pension checks it has been sending its retired police officers, firefighters and other workers by as much as half. All the city promises now is that its retirees, many of whom do not get Social Security, will not have their benefits cut to less than $10,000 a year.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Michael Cooper

articles.headline: Conventional Fed Wisdom, Defied
articles.snippet: Thomas Hoenig, the soon-to-be former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, spoke early and often against banks that engage in risky business.
articles.abstract: Thomas Hoenig, the soon-to-be former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, spoke early and often against banks that engage in risky business.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWS last week that the Federal Reserve would keep interest rates near zero until mid-2013 was welcomed by many investors, but the bleak message about the economy still came through loud and clear.

articles.headline: Buy, Sell, Hold (Tight): Eight Days of Market Frenzy
articles.snippet: From the trading rooms to the living rooms of market insiders across the country, it’s been a harrowing time.
articles.abstract: From the trading rooms to the living rooms of market insiders across the country, it’s been a harrowing time.
articles.lead_paragraph: ONE of the most harrowing stretches in Wall Street history began with the loss of the AAA credit rating of the United States and ended with fears of a new recession. In between, the wild swings in the financial markets captivated the nation, and the world.
articles.byline: By David Segal, Charles Duhigg and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: Tribal Rifts Threaten to Undermine Libya Uprising
articles.snippet: An increase in discord and factionalism among rebels could threaten the effort to overthrow Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and put Libyan civilians at risk.
articles.abstract: An increase in discord and factionalism among rebels could threaten the effort to overthrow Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and put Libyan civilians at risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Saddled with infighting and undermined by the occasionally ruthless and undisciplined behavior of its fighters, the six-month-old rebel uprising against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi is showing signs of sliding from a struggle to overthrow an autocrat into a murkier contest between factions and tribes.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and C. J. Chivers

articles.headline: Starved Budgets Inspire New Look at Web Gambling
articles.snippet: States are looking to Internet gambling as part of the antidote to their budget woes, but could run into trouble with the Justice Department.
articles.abstract: States are looking to Internet gambling as part of the antidote to their budget woes, but could run into trouble with the Justice Department.
articles.lead_paragraph: The District of Columbia is not thrilled that its residents are traveling to Maryland, Pennsylvania and West Virginia to gamble in casinos. Starved for cash, like states across the country, the district wants some of the millions in revenue that gambling generates each year.

articles.headline: Chinese Director’s Path From Rebel to Insider
articles.snippet: Zhao Liang’s evolution from a filmmaker the government hounded to one it celebrates offers a window into how directors in China try to carve out space for self-expression.
articles.abstract: Zhao Liang’s evolution from a filmmaker the government hounded to one it celebrates offers a window into how directors in China try to carve out space for self-expression.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The documentary film “Petition” by Zhao Liang is considered by many of its viewers to be a fearless work of art. Shot over 12 years, it shows how the authorities muzzle and brutalize Chinese who, following an age-old tradition, travel to Beijing seeking redress for wrongdoing by local officials.

articles.headline: Iowa Poll Goes to Bachmann; Paul Is Second
articles.snippet: The results of the straw poll represented a turning point in the campaign but also underscored an uncertainty in the Republican contest to find a presidential nominee.
articles.abstract: The results of the straw poll represented a turning point in the campaign but also underscored an uncertainty in the Republican contest to find a presidential nominee.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMES, Iowa — The race for the Republican presidential nomination came into sharper focus on Saturday as Gov. Rick Perry of Texas declared his candidacy in South Carolina and Michele Bachmann won a closely watched poll of voters in Iowa.

articles.headline: White House Debates Fight on Economy
articles.snippet: As millions battle unemployment, the Obama administration is considering whether to adopt a more combative approach on the economy.
articles.abstract: As millions battle unemployment, the Obama administration is considering whether to adopt a more combative approach on the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the economy worsens, President Obama and his senior aides are considering whether to adopt a more combative approach on economic issues, seeking to highlight substantive differences with Republicans in Congress and on the campaign trail rather than continuing to pursue elusive compromises, advisers to the president say.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Setbacks May Push Europe Into a New Downturn
articles.snippet: Flagging output, a sovereign debt maelstrom and market tumult have people wondering if Europe can sustain its recovery.
articles.abstract: Flagging output, a sovereign debt maelstrom and market tumult have people wondering if Europe can sustain its recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Economists may still be debating whether Europe is headed for a sharp slowdown or even a recession, but Steve Knott, who installs home heating systems in Barrow-in-Furness, a port town in northwest England once known for its iron mills, is convinced he already knows the answer.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Julia Werdigier

articles.headline: Syrian Navy Joins Attack on Key Rebellious Port City
articles.snippet: At least 25 people were killed in Latakia, activists and residents said, as the government escalated its attempt to repress dissent.
articles.abstract: At least 25 people were killed in Latakia, activists and residents said, as the government escalated its attempt to repress dissent.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In yet another escalation of its crackdown on dissent, the Syrian government unleashed navy vessels, tanks and a mix of soldiers, security forces and paramilitary fighters against the port city of Latakia on Sunday, killing at least 25 people, including three children, activists and residents said.

articles.headline: As Networks Speed Up, Data Hits a Wall
articles.snippet: Cellphone plans that let people gobble up unlimited data are disappearing as new data-heavy services catch on.
articles.abstract: Cellphone plans that let people gobble up unlimited data are disappearing as new data-heavy services catch on.
articles.lead_paragraph: The newest smartphones are intended to run on speedy 4G networks that allow people to effortlessly stream music, watch Netflix movies and tune in live to a Mets game, wherever they are.

articles.headline: Who Is to Blame if Shares Continue Steep Declines?
articles.snippet: When market gyrations become excessive, governments hope they stem from market imperfections, not fundamental problems.
articles.abstract: When market gyrations become excessive, governments hope they stem from market imperfections, not fundamental problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a tale told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing.

articles.headline: Flash-Sale Site Shifts Its Model
articles.snippet: The Gilt Groupe is also starting to sell merchandise at full price as it figures out how to cope with a mending economy.
articles.abstract: The Gilt Groupe is also starting to sell merchandise at full price as it figures out how to cope with a mending economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent day on Gilt.com, shoppers could buy 10 round-trip tickets on Virgin America for $3,585, three sessions of laser hair-removal for $352 or eight Alaskan king salmon fillets for $118.95.

articles.headline: Market Ills Give CNBC a Bounce
articles.snippet: CNBC — not its smaller rivals — seems to be gaining the most from interest in the downgrade of the United States debt rating and concern over European banks.
articles.abstract: CNBC — not its smaller rivals — seems to be gaining the most from interest in the downgrade of the United States debt rating and concern over European banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Nik Deogun was running the financial coverage of The Wall Street Journal during the crisis in 2008, he kept a constant eye on CNBC as the events played out on television. “It was news being made, all the time, in real time,” he said.

articles.headline: Low Rates May Do Little to Entice Nervous Consumers
articles.snippet: Low interest rates, which usually persuade consumers to spend, are not working this time for reasons including anxiety over jobs and tighter lending standards.
articles.abstract: Low interest rates, which usually persuade consumers to spend, are not working this time for reasons including anxiety over jobs and tighter lending standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s announcement last week that it intended to keep credit cheap for at least two more years was a clear invitation to Americans: Go out and borrow.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Smuggling in North Sinai Surges as the Police Vanish
articles.snippet: As law enforcement returns elsewhere in Egypt six months after the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak, there is still almost no sign of the police in Bedouin-dominated North Sinai.
articles.abstract: As law enforcement returns elsewhere in Egypt six months after the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak, there is still almost no sign of the police in Bedouin-dominated North Sinai.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAFAH, Egypt — The smuggler’s car lot is so brazenly out in the open, it is hard to tell that the business is actually illegal.

articles.headline: A Businessman in Congress Helps His District and Himself
articles.snippet: Representative Darrell Issa’s private and business lives often overlap, with at least some of his government actions helping make him richer.
articles.abstract: Representative Darrell Issa’s private and business lives often overlap, with at least some of his government actions helping make him richer.
articles.lead_paragraph: VISTA, Calif. — Here on the third floor of a gleaming office building overlooking a golf course in the rugged foothills north of San Diego, Darrell Issa, the entrepreneur, oversees the hub of a growing financial empire worth hundreds of millions of dollars.

articles.headline: After Iowa, Republicans Face a New Landscape
articles.snippet: With Tim Pawlenty out of the fight, a three-way race began taking shape to find a nominee who can emerge as the strongest challenger to President Obama.
articles.abstract: With Tim Pawlenty out of the fight, a three-way race began taking shape to find a nominee who can emerge as the strongest challenger to President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WATERLOO, Iowa — The leading Republican presidential candidates scrambled to take command of a new landscape on Sunday after Tim Pawlenty abruptly ended his campaign and a three-way race began taking shape to find a nominee who can emerge as the strongest challenger to President Obama.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Threat Resurges in Deadliest Day of Year for Iraq
articles.snippet: A series of attacks sent the message to Iraq and the United States that after tens of thousands of lives lost and hundreds of billions of dollars spent, insurgents remain a threat.
articles.abstract: A series of attacks sent the message to Iraq and the United States that after tens of thousands of lives lost and hundreds of billions of dollars spent, insurgents remain a threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A chilling series of fatal attacks across Iraq on Monday sent a disheartening message to the Iraqi and American governments: After hundreds of billions of dollars spent since the United States invasion in 2003, and tens of thousands of lives lost, insurgents remain a potent and perhaps resurging threat to Iraqis and the American troops still in the country.
